It's true that a patient cannot be discharged while a QIO appeal is pending however it's not necessarily the case that Medicare 'continues' to pay. More likely than not the hospital's payment basis involves a case rate for the admission based on something called a DRG (diagnosis related group) derived from a 'grouping' of diagnosis and procedure codes. DRGs include a certain number of days of inpatient care as part of the flat rate payment. The sooner a patient is discharged the better the hospital makes out financially, freeing a bed for another admission and another case rate payment. Medicare has to an extent addressed this perverse incentive by docking hospitals' payments when they execute a 'quick and sick' discharge to a skilled nursing facility as opposed to keeping the patient a day or two longer and discharging home with home health care. It's all a game of sorts. Affordable care organizations (ACOs) will, it's to be hoped, address some of this by getting all parties to an episode of care on the same team.

For the record, Massachusetts does have a QIO, MassPro in Waltham which handles these appeals for that state. So does New Hampshire, the Northeast Health Care Quality Foundation.

The last time I was in the hospital, I couldn't make the telephone at my bedside work (partly because I had limited use of one arm).  Knowing that the hospital wouldn't like my using a cell phone, I hadn't brought it.  Suppose I had wanted to dispute my discharge?  What then?

Wait a second. Medicare won't pay for days in the hospital that aren't "required" by the patients' medical conditions...that's why hospitals want patients discharged when they are medically stable (let's ignore the above unusual example in the article for now about a dying patient). So Medicare will pay for the days during their QIO assessment? Great! Hospitals will welcome patients contesting their own discharge since then those days, which the patient wants and which will help further iron out patient issues, will be actually paid for instead of provided for free. I don't deal with the $/administrative issues when providing care as a physician, but I do not know a physician who would *ever* discharge a patient they thought could not cope at home. Finally, hospitals are punished for early re-admissions....a natural consequence for too-early release. I think this service is wonderful and encourage it, but it's need may often be due to misunderstandings (actually like the one above).

Let me clarify.   When a Q.I.O. deems that a Medicare beneficiary needs to stay in the hospital, it is not allowed to bill that beneficiary extra for the additional time spent in the hospital.  The cost of that stay is Medicare's responsibility.  You're right that Medicare pays a fixed amount for a given diagnosis.  But there are variables also, such as the cost of some drug therapies that aren't included in the DRG rates.  In any case, the point is that no extra financial responsibility (beyond existing deductibles and co-payments) will fall on the patient because of a longer stay.

" Medicare will cover the extra time spent in the hospital". Medicare pays a set dollar amount for a given diagnosis. The hospital does not get " extra payment". The hospital has to accept what medicare gives them. The loser in this case is the hospital, not Medicare. Just wait until you see all the small ( especially rural) hospitals that close in the next few years as " Medicare"  ( the Federal Government) saves money by not paying hospitals for legitimate services. America, you get what you pay for.....

I agree with you, as a hospitalist i often encounter families and patients who want to delay discharge for their convenience, and want outpatient studies unrelated to their admission diagnosis done in the hospital (ie a patient with chf who wanted his annual colonsocopy done during his inpt stay).  Also have experience with families who want grandma to stay in the hospital until after a family party, trip etc, and families who refuse to discuss nursing home placement until their frail family member has been denied acute rehab...but in our hospital culture we have to provide great customer service.  No need to appeal to an OIO here, just call our "guest relations" number and you can stay as long as you like.

And there are also hospitals and discharge planners who take advantage of patients' families. I found little, if any, sympathy with NY Presbyterian Hospital and doctors affiliated with it in connection with my late mother's illnesses. Because I was "the daughter" and "the health care proxy" who accompanied her to medical appts. they assumed I was more or less free all day every day, and when I took time off from work and arranged to go get my mother upon discharge, frequently found the social worker, residents who had written the discharge instructions, et al busy someplace and unavailable at the agreed-upon hour for discharge. Meanwhile, the meter was running on the car that was waiting downstairs to get us to her apartment.

I always tell people who have jobs they at least want to try to keep that when they have to leave the office on one of these parent-related medical errands, to take the amount of time they think this mission should take and at least double or triple it and that is what they should tell their boss vis a vis their anticipated return time.

I am an internist in practice for twenty-eight years. I still do both office-based and hospital medicine. In those twenty-eight years, I have had a hospital discharge appealed only once. An elderly woman had been admitted for lower GI bleeding, which stabilized and stopped. The next day, I informed the daughter on a Monday evening that if she remained stable (i.e. her blood count did not drop) for the next eighteen hours, she could then be discharged.

The daughter approached me and said "Doctor, I need you to do me a favor. I don't want her discharged until Wednesday, because my son is off work and can pick her up, but not tomorrow." I told the daughter that making arrangements to deliberately delay discharge (for more than 24 hours past the point where patient was stable) was a violation of Medicare rules. Bear in mind, she was asking on a Monday to delay discharge on a Wednesday, two days later.

I had the social worker explain transportation options (taxi, car service, wheelchair van--though she was not wheelchair-confined) but the daughter refused them all. When at noon on Tuesday I determined that her situation was stable (no bleeding for two days), I wrote discharge orders. The family appealed the discharge, and the discharge planning nurse informed her she would receive a call from the QIO to state her case.

The daughter's reply: "Oh, I don't need to talk to them, I just don't want my mother discharged until tomorrow". Appeal was dropped, but family got a delay.

It's hoped that this will change with the new policy that Medicare will not pay for readmission for the same malady within 30 days.  I know our small local hospital is doing more to see to it that patients have access to care when they are released.

The QIO in California stepped right in when the hospital attempted to prematurely discharge my MIL without an adequate plan. But I'm a nerd, and actually read all the documents I'm given, and am pretty good with Google. The reality is that most people covered by Medicare don't have the skills (and probably don't have computer access while they're in the hospital) to understand their options, and neither do their family members.

Hospitals push a tremendous amount of paper at slightly addled patients and stressed family members, and they want it all signed RIGHT NOW. They don't care whether pharmacies are open and have the requested drugs right now, they don't figure out if the patient has the right kind of help at home to help with transfers, or the supplies or training to help the patient.

What is missing is real discharge planning -- with a real patient advocate who could and would ask the hard questions, including whether the receiving environment (rehab hospital, nursing home, home) is adequately prepared to handle the patient at this level of illness or injury. Discharging an elderly patient who is unsteady and disoriented to an equally elderly and frail spouse is a recipe for another crisis.

We found that the hospital jumps quickly enough when the doctor says "discharge," but neither the hospital nor the doctors invite the family or any advocate into a process to figure out what needs to happen to make the discharge successful.

I think NYS has more rules governing than just about anywhere else; thus there is some bit of protection if you or someone can speak up. The issue of concern comes down - for the hospital - to  whether or not it will be paid for days if not approved by Medicare.

I don't know about other states, but in New York either the patient or his or her representative has to more or less agree to the terms of the discharge.I am not aware of people who refuse to agree to it being thrown out.
